utterances: Venezuelan Foreign Minister Nicholas Maduro charges that by sacking Chavez, Uribe showed he didn't really want an accord.
(Through translator) They don't believe in peace.
They don't bet on peace.
They're too tied to the interest of war.
But Uribe insists his government has worked hard for a deal.
(Through translator) We've made all the efforts; the response, killings and lies.
In her emotional letter, Betancourt tells her mother life in a jungle is dismal.
Her companions are male guerrillas.

She asked for books, the answer is always no. She says that, quote, ""I'm not as resistant, as courageous, as intelligent, or as strong as I thought."" Death, she says, sometimes seems like a sweet option.
She says she doesn't know how long she can last.
Writing now for her children, she says...
So much of life has passed us by as if the horizon were disappearing in the distance.
They are the same and they are others.

And each second of my absence, of not being able to be there for them, of caring for their pain, of being unable to advise them, give them strength, show patience and humility in the face of life's blows, all those opportunities lost for a mother, poisoned the moments of infinite loneliness as a cyanide had been put in my veins, drop by drop.
Juan Forero, NPR News, Bogota, Colombia.
And now a note about a pioneering adventurer of a different sort, one who reached the highest peaks right here on Earth.
Agnes Veille was one of the first women mountain climbers in America.
Her name was back in the news this week because some climbers in Colorado have been trying to get a peak named after her.
So far, their efforts have been rebuffed.
There are only six major mountains that remain unnamed in Colorado, and so competition is fierce.
Veille was a bold climber, who in the 1920s was on course to become the first woman to summit all 54 of Colorado's 14,000-foot peaks.
But Veille never reached her goal because in 1925 she met her doom on the top of Longs Peak.
She had reached the summit at about 4 a.m. and was beginning her descent when she fell.
She survived the fall and asked her climbing partner to go for help.
A blizzard came in as she waited, and Agnes Veille froze to death.
The forest around here is under government protection, yet Bolsonaro talks of loosening Brazil's environmental licensing laws because he thinks they suffocate the economy.
Brazil's powerful agri-business lobby, hungry for new land for farming and mining, is behind him, says Ribeiro.
In the forest around Eldorado, there are about a dozen quilombolas.
These are small, impoverished Afro-Brazilian communities, often established centuries ago by Africans who escaped slavery.
These days, Bolsonaro says he sees all Brazilians as equal.
Yet in the quilombolas, people haven't forgotten his past racist remarks about them, says Talia Moraes (ph), who lives in one.
(Through interpreter) People say he's very prejudiced and that he does like blacks, so we feel really offended.
Local officials say Bolsonaro lived in Eldorado from the age of 5 to 18.
His father was the town dentist.
(Speaking Portuguese).
Irineu Pedroso (ph), vice principal of a local school, says he and Bolsonaro hung out as kids, swimming in the rivers, playing soccer and hunting birds.
His mom was a washerwoman in the Bolsonaro household, he says.
Pedroso's politically on the left and dreads Bolsonaro becoming president.
(Speaking Portuguese).
A president should unite people, not divide them like Bolsonaro,"" he argues.
Night is creeping in across the rainforest.
In a house on Eldorado's big town square, the mayor and his deputy are guests at an awards ceremony for locals who've completed fashion and bakery courses.
These two officials belong to a centrist political party, yet they say they don't see Bolsonaro, from the far-right, as a threat.
(Speaking Portuguese).
If Bolsonaro becomes president, I'm sure he'll look kindly on the town,"" says Vice Mayor Dionel Rocha (ph).
But what about the Atlantic rainforest all around?
(Speaking Portuguese).
The forest is Eldorado's greatest treasure,"" says Mayor Durval de Morais, ""and the lungs of the region."" Yet, the town's broke - it needs income and jobs, he says.
So it should profit from the forest, allowing in what he calls non-polluting industries, and protect it.
You can do both,"" says de Morais.
(Speaking Portuguese).
And I believe Jair Bolsonaro knows that,"" he says.
Lelis Ribeiro, the Eldorado eco-tourist guide, disagrees.
(Speaking Portuguese).
Bolsonaro doesn't have any conservation policies,"" says Ribiero.
So any form of threat to the Atlantic rainforest is terrible,"" he says, ""because once you lose it, you'll never get it back."" Philip Reeves, NPR News, Eldorado.
And if you want to get a bit closer to Florida's fish than the view of Mitchell Roffer gets from a satellite, soon you'll be able to scuba dive under the sea without leaving your living room.
A survey of the coral reefs off the Florida Keys is being done using the same fish eye camera lenses that Google uses to capture street view images.
Researches and scientists will use the images to measure the effects of climate change, pollution and fishing on the reefs.
This is the first time this has been done in the U.S.
But the Caitlin Seaview Survey has already recorded 400,000 images off the coasts of Australia and around the Caribbean.
The project is funded by the insurance company Catlin Group, which hopes the data will help them understand how insurance risks could be managed in the future.
How exactly that works, we're not sure.
But it's probably safe to say it won't bring down your car insurance rate.
What it will mean, though, is that you can explore the deep sea from your computer when some of these images are made available on Google Maps.
This is DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
And I'm Alex Cohen.
It's mail call in Washington D.C.
Hundreds of thousands of letters calling for immigration reform will be delivered to Congress today by a Spanish-language morning talk show host named Eddie Piolin Sotelo, or Piolin.
His syndicated show, ""Piolin por la Manana,"" is heard in 27 cities across the U.S.
It's the top-rated morning show in Los Angeles.
Recently, Piolin has been calling on listeners to write to lawmakers, urging them to pass fair and just immigration reform.
This week he's doing his show from the road, picking up letters from people in Albuquerque, Dallas and Chicago.
We spoke with Piolin earlier as he was headed to the Capitol.
How many letters have you collected so far?
More than a million letters.
Wow.
What are you driving?
Where do you fitting all those letters in?
We have a trailer where we have the stack of the letters there.
What are some of the things that people have written in these letters?

Okay, what it says is that we are against separating families and everybody who's been working so hard for the better economy of the nation, they can have an opportunity who would stay here, you know, legally.
Piolin, are you yourself an immigrant?
Yes, I am.
And you came to this country, how long ago?
That was in 1986.
I came from Mexico.
And what about your experience do you think it's important for lawmakers to know as they discuss immigration?
Yes.
I think it's important because there's so many people that come here to be able to help our family.
For example, when I came here in 1986, I was able to help my family to buy a house - for my dad and my mom.
At the same time I was able to go to school, and I was able to start here to become a radio announcer.
And I remember once when I got fired from one of the companies (unintelligible) because I didn't have my documentation, I didn't have my Green Card.
Piolin, immigration reform isn't faring too well in Congress.
What do you hope the effect of all these letters that you'll deliver will be?
It would be 10 years before another woman, Mary Cronin, would accomplish Veille's dream.
Cronin, by the way, does have a peak named for her.
The local Chaffee County Commission believes Veille has been sufficiently honored with the waterfall and shelter that carry her name.
But those who carry the torch for Veille had appealed their case to the U.S.
Geological Surveys Board on Geographic Names and are awaiting a decision.
The new pitcher for the Boston Red Sox, Daisuke Matsuzaka, is making his home debut.
The Red Sox scooped him up from a Japanese team in a $103 million deal, and more buzz and hype surrounded him than anyone else in baseball.
NPR'S Chris Arnold reports.
It doesn't matter that before tonight, Matsuzaka hasn't pitched a single game at Fenway Park and has only pitched once in the major leagues.
Red Sox fans truly are fanatics, so the idea that they've landed a pitcher who could become one of the best in baseball is like throwing gasoline on a fire.
(SOUNDBITE OF EXCITED CROWD)
I think he's going to take us all the way.
At a bar outside Fenway before opening day, yesterday, Janelle Lovell(ph) and Alice Atkinson(ph), both nurses, were very fired up about Matsuzaka.
They're wearing Dice-K Japanese rising sun headbands and have big, fuzzy red dice hanging around their necks.
